Causal Inference in Epidemiology

This comprehensive PhD-level course explores the theory and application of causal inference methods in epidemiological research. The materials cover everything from foundational concepts to advanced methodological approaches and practical implementations.

Course Structure

The course is organized into modules covering theoretical frameworks, methodological approaches, and practical applications, with hands-on R programming exercises throughout.

  • Theoretical foundations: counterfactual theory, DAGs, structural equation models
  • Methodological approaches: propensity score methods, inverse probability weighting, g-methods
  • Practical applications in infectious disease, chronic disease, environmental epidemiology
  • Interactive R programming labs and data analysis projects

Learning Outcomes

After completing this tutorial series, you will be able to:

  • Apply causal thinking to epidemiological research questions
  • Construct and interpret directed acyclic graphs (DAGs)
  • Implement various causal inference methods using R
  • Select appropriate methods for different research scenarios
  • Critically evaluate causal claims in the published literature
Start Learning View Course Outline

Prerequisites

These tutorials are designed for different levels of expertise. The causal inference course assumes:

  • Strong foundation in epidemiological methods
  • Intermediate to advanced statistical knowledge
  • Basic programming skills in R
  • Understanding of regression analysis and study design

Each tutorial will clearly indicate any specific prerequisites or recommended background knowledge.
